subject: HardwareIsolation: Added the "Create" interface
commitMessage:
HardwareIsolation: Added the "Create" interface

In an OpenPOWER based system, the user can isolate hardware,
and the respective isolated hardware part will be ignored
to init during the next boot of the host.

This interface can be used by a user to manually isolate
hardware and we don't have/generate the event log because
this is not an error case and the user voluntarily tried to
isolate hardware.

The added method will throw below exceptions.
- xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.InvalidArgument
  - If the given parameters are invalid.
  - If the given hardware is not found to isolate.
- xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.TooManyResources
  - If the platforms are not allowed to isolate hardware
    when the isolated hardware count is reached to the maximum
    allowed size.
- xyz.openbmc_project.HardwareIsolation.Error.IsolatedAlready
  - If the isolating hardware is already isolated.
- xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.NotAllowed
  - If the given hardware cannot be isolated permanently.
- xyz.openbmc_project.Common.Error.Unavailable
  - If the given hardware cannot be isolated temporarily.

Please refer https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/docs/+/27804
to get more details of hardware isolation.

Signed-off-by: Ramesh Iyyar <rameshi1@in.ibm.com>
Change-Id: I8868e0f7e07694a902b790a909ee7ff20272ca81

OpenPOWER - is the correct usage.
Ack
if any hardware part needs to be isolated?
Ack
PEL ID? instead of using BmcErrorLogId.

I am preferring BMCErrorLog because it can be used in isolated hardware entry to form a redfish response.

and I guess this interface can be triggered in PEL infrastructure (which already may know the bmc error log id) or directly from the application which can get through https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/org/open_power/Logging/PEL.interface.yaml#L63  

Any different opinion?
All the errors including host are committed in BMC only. the name"BMC" is little confusing here

Agree but, I think we have different types of id's to error log in the openpower context, for example, BMC Event Log ID which can use to pull the PEL ID, PLID, and EID based on needs.

I felt it will confuse the consumer of this interface like which one needs to pass so, mentioning the exact id which is expected by this interface, and if this interface getting bmc event id then, we can get whatever we need from BMC Event log. 

Or what about this "EventLogID"?
am ok with this name.
BMC
Ack
the*
Ack
This version should be in an openbmc-project.xyz interface.

Yeah true but felt the same as other change comments (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/43532/4//COMMIT_MSG#12)

I think I can move once I got feedback for the above comment.
Done
Where does this "key" come from?  Why isn't your PLDM provider performing the translation?

This is key is coming from PHAL (POWER Hardware Abstraction Layer) i.e there is CEC (Central Electronics Complex) device tree which contains BMC and HostBoot interested cec hardware details and each hardware having a key called "EntityPath".

PHAL layer will push into upstream (OpenPOWER) shortly and this layer will be used in openPOWER based BMC applications (openpower-proc-control, openpower-hw-diags) so those applications may interested to isolate many other hardwares which are not modeled in inventory. 

Today, we are modeling Core and Dimm through PLDM and the remaining BMC interested POWER processor subunits (hardware for example Memory Controller, etc..) details we are pulling from the PHAL CEC device tree. 

This version (entity path) of the interface will be used by BMC openPOWER based applications to isolate hardware.

> PHAL layer will push into upstream (OpenPOWER) shortly and this layer will be used in openPOWER based BMC applications (openpower-proc-control, openpower-hw-diags) so those applications may interested to isolate many other hardwares which are not modeled in inventory. 

This statement is implying an entire design which has not been discussed with the open source community.  We don't currently have "libraries" like what you're suggesting here.  It is disappointing that it sounds like you're team has gone off and written a bunch of code in a closed manner and then are expecting to drop it on the rest of us when it doesn't fit the rest of the software design.
Yeah, Agree. are you saying we (the community) won't encourage to use "libraries" when there is a dbus to talk between processes?

Phal application uses as Entity path as common key between Hostboot targetting and device tree,
Considering this design direction better to provide Entity path based interface for PHal application and avoid using Physical path based interfaces. physical path is almost arbitrary based on how the mrw gets filled in, packaging can change it and numbering is "fluid". entity path is more formalized with meaning so less likely to be weird for different systems.

This interface will support both so, consumers of this interface can decide how they want. 

Or Do we need to remove this support from the interface?

I know, there is a guard tool to do the same activity and just providing the same support in dbus as well.
Gneral design direction , followed here is use entity path as common key considering future use cases. . Unless you got strong use case to use physical path.

You can use entity path also in this interface. 

I think you are talking why need "third" type, there are hardwares which is not available inventory (today).
so, to isolate that we need to use entity path which is an array of byte and it can not understand by the user (lab user/developer). 

Today, we are using the guard tool to use human-understandable format to isolate something so, the same support can be given in dbus as well right?  ​

Key point you need to consider here is to avoid usage of physical path based interface in the production code.

Another problem statement i heard from guard tool users( dev/test/lab) , how to get guardable units information , to create guard records. to get entity path ot physical path , need to look devtree for gettibg this info. If you can  provide some  option in tool or interface  to dump guardable units keys  based on the type , that will be more useful.

> Key point you need to consider here is to avoid usage of physical path based interface in the production code.

Why? We can not trust? If so, I can go and remove this support.
I am not seeing any data like we can not trust/use the physical path in some cases.  

> Another problem statement i heard from guard tool users( dev/test/lab) , how to get guardable units information , to create guard records. to get entity path ot physical path , need to look devtree for gettibg this info. If you can  provide some  option in tool or interface  to dump guardable units keys  based on the type , that will be more useful.

Looks you are coming with a new requirement which we won't support today,
You can create an issue and we can track and implement that and Yes, it will be really useful for dev/test/lab users.

OK, I will remove the support (physical path) from dbus because our end goal is to model all the isolatable hardware into bmc inventory and after that, those additional types are useless except the first type.

is it fine?
Can this be a path to the event object?

This interface can be used by an external user to manually isolate hardware and we don't have/generate the event log because this is not an error case and the user voluntarily tried to isolate hardware.

and I think we can not use optional parameter in dbus right? Please let me know if there is a way to do that if it makes sense to you.

or Any different thoughts?

> and I think we can not use optional parameter in dbus right? Please let me know if there is a way to do that if it makes sense to you.

Correct, there are no optional values.  If you want a way to create manual entries without a corresponding log, when most of the non-manual cases have a log, you'll need a separate method for that.

Can the entry, when it exists, be a path?

> If you want a way to create manual entries without a corresponding log, when most of the non-manual cases have a log, you'll need a separate method for that.

Yeah, that is doable like "Create" and "CreateWithErrorLog" 

> Can the entry, when it exists, be a path?

I am not sure, I got your point fully. Correct me if I am wrong.
I guess you meant the event log entry can exist while trying to isolate hardware?

I think it depends on when this interface is called.
I guess if an error log entry does not exist, I think we will get the below error from dbus-broker while calling this interface?

> Peer :X.XXX is being disconnected as it sent a message with an invalid body.

What I noticed is, when I am sending a dbus object which does not exist, I got the above error, and after looking dbus-broker got to know that when I am passing signature with "o" it making sure that given object exists or not
Ack
I think we've been trying to eliminate these InternalFailures as much as possible.  Do we have any better error definition for what is happening in your daemon?

Ah ok make sense since we can not get the exact reason but, the daemon which will implement this interface using a library (libguard) from openPOWER to create a record into the PNOR partition and it throwing runtime exception so I thought to use Interfailure in those cases.
Again, we don't have libraries like this.  Won't this all be in the "guard" daemon (ie. the implementation of this interface).

Yeah, I think we can do it, maybe port and refactor the libguard code from a bmc perspective if we strictly not encouraging libraries in openBMC?

OR Can we do stage by stage i.e first pass with libguard and second pass implement in daemon itself? if strictly no libraries?
Under what conditions would it be "NotAllowed"?

We have a use case to check whether the maximum count reached to create the record in PNOR so, I thought will throw this error if the count is reached and could not create the record for isolating hardware.

Please don't reuse Common.Errors for non-standard purposes.  "NotAllowed" is typically used in for a bad state request.  (Eg. someone asked to power on a device and the device is already powered on)

I think it would be better to define your own error for this case unless you can find an existing common error that more succinctly encapsulates the error condition.  Maybe Common.Error.TooManyResources.

> Please don't reuse Common.Errors for non-standard purposes.  "NotAllowed" is typically used in for a bad state request.  (Eg. someone asked to power on a device and the device is already powered on)

Oh ok, I am not aware of this. I assumed like for some reason the dbus interfaces operation is not allowing us to do something to throw an error.

But, Agree the use case which referring to is a non-standard one.  

> I think it would be better to define your own error for this case unless you can find an existing common error that more succinctly encapsulates the error condition.  Maybe Common.Error.TooManyResources.

I think "TooManyResources" will fit for this use case but, Yes I will try to see if more error case is coming then I will define own errors for this daemon.
Ack

Why need this separate interface for user Guard, Can we use the proposed create interface and type as "User" ? and the back-end application can decide, required to cerate error log or not incase user type. 
Or is there any other use case for this create interface?

> Why need this separate interface for user Guard, Can we use the proposed create interface and type as "User" ? 

This is interface gives flexibility to the consumer if they don't want to create an error log but want to isolate hardware irrespective of type.

> the back-end application can decide, required to cerate error log or not incase user type. 

The intention of this interface doesn't want to create an error log just to isolate hardware from the boot of the host.

are you seeing any use cases to create an error log by the manager of this interface instead of creating by the consumer of this interface? If this interface wants to create the error log means what are the error log details you will be expected to give?

In openBMC, we already have an interface to create an error log (https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/master/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Create.interface.yaml) and so why you cannot use that interface and pass that created error log path into another proposed interface (https://gerrit.openbmc-project.xyz/c/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/+/44229).

and why we need to mingle the responsibility hardware isolation and bmc event log managers here? - I am thinking like why this interface needs to act as a mediator to just create an error log by getting all the expected input from the consumer and pass it to the bmc event log manager OR why the implementor of this interface needs to act as another bmc log manager?  

> is there any other use case for this create interface?

In few platforms, vendors don't want to create an error log when the user isolating hardware because it may not an error case for them.
I think you can easily achive by adding property , related to this error log required or not.

Still I am preferring "Create" and "CreateWithErrorLog" methods - I feel, If we have abstracted like this we can avoid extra activity (which you said) in both side (consumer and implementer of this interface).

for user requested isolation error needs to be returned 
- if the hardware is already isolated
- if the hardware cannot be isolated
Done
Also these ones: what is your user suppose to do with these?

Agree with you, the user of this interface cannot do anything with those error and all are internal errors
but, I cannot use InternalFailure (and I heard, Interfailure will trigger bmc dump)? Can I use it?

and I think we discussed like, "NotAllowed" also can not use since it have specific reason (standard error) in BMC.

We probably need broader consensus on what to do for error paths like this.

My initial feeling is that the daemon should terminate itself on Open/Seek/Read/Write fails, which will as a side effect cause the dbus-call to fail plus a core dump of the daemon.  By sending it out the dbus, you are effectively ignoring it inside your own daemon and not allowing the most likely successful recovery to be done (restarting the daemon).

The way the dbus framework currently works you cannot both respond (such as with NotAllowed) and crash your daemon (by throwing an exception out of the response-handler).  In any case the NotAllowed is a similar "what does the client do with this?".  With the "daemon crashed in the middle of the call" state we could at least insert code into sdbusplus to catch this condition and potentially retry or at least turn it into a well-formed sdbusplus exception which would allow the client to retry on its own.

>My initial feeling is that the daemon should terminate itself on Open/Seek/Read/Write fails, which will as a side effect cause the dbus-call to fail plus a core dump of the daemon.

Yes I have noticed this and I wondered about core dump because in my early my experience (Telecom) we will care about core dump and service availability but, Looks openBMC following some principle on this (some service reset policy - trying to gather information on this) and I will agree, it will vary based on project scope.

is the openbmc design principle is like follow, should throw an exception from daemon and dbus-call (handler of this interface (auto-generated code)) will fail and it start core dump and restart the daemon. If so, I will remove those FileError from all create interfaces.

> The way the dbus framework currently works you cannot both respond (such as with NotAllowed) and crash your daemon (by throwing an exception out of the response-handler).
Good info, I will keep it in my mind and it will help in the future to think more about this.

> In any case the NotAllowed is a similar "what does the client do with this?".  With the "daemon crashed in the middle of the call" state we could at least insert code into sdbusplus to catch this condition and potentially retry or at least turn it into a well-formed sdbusplus exception which would allow the client to retry on its own.

Today, are there any retry mechanisms from sdbusplus? I have looked at the auto-generated code of interfaces like how it calling sdbusplus api "C++" -> dbus api ("C") but, not sure I missed anything in this - May be discord discussion If so, I can connect with you?
Ack, Removed File-related errors and if those errors occurred then, the daemon will restart to recover from that error.
